stem: The nurse is analyzing the fluid status for two clients on a medical-surgical unit. Based on the documentation in the Fluid Status Dashboard, match each finding to the correct fluid volume state.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 82-year-old male with dementia. Found in home by caregiver today. Reports not drinking for 'days'. Skin is pale and dry.
Patient B: 66-year-old female with CHF. Reports being unable to put on her shoes. Breathing is labored and she has had a cough for 24 hours.

tabs.title: Fluid Status Dashboard
tabs.content:
Patient48-Hour Intake48-Hour OutputWeight Change
Patient A800 mL2,400 mL-2.2 kg (4.8 lbs)
Patient B3,500 mL1,200 mL+3.1 kg (6.8 lbs)

tabs.title: Vital Signs & Labs
tabs.content:
Patient A: BP 88/54, HR 122, Hct 54%, BUN 42.
Patient B: BP 172/98, HR 104, Hct 32%, BNP 1,200.

rows.text: Intake is significantly less than output (Negative balance).
Rapid weight gain (> 2 lbs in 24 hours).
Elevated Hematocrit (Hct) and Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN).
Peripheral edema and audible crackles in lung bases.

rationale.correct: Fluid Volume Deficit (FVD) (c1) is characterized by a negative fluid balance (r1), hemoconcentration (r3), and lack of venous pressure (r4). Fluid Volume Excess (FVE) (c2) presents with rapid weight gain (r2) and fluid leaking into tissues or lungs (r5). Patient A's dashboard proves 2.2kg loss (Dry), while Patient B's proofs show 3.1kg gain (Wet).
clinicalPearls: 1 kg of weight change = 1 Liter of fluid.
In FVD, the pulse is typically THREADY and weak. In FVE, the pulse is BOUNDING and strong.
The BUN typically rises more than the Creatinine in FVD (Dehydration).

questionTrap.trap: Believing that high BUN always means kidney failure.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the Creatinine is normal but the BUN is high, it usually indicates dehydration (FVD) or GI bleeding.

mnemonic.title: Concentration Check
mnemonic.expansion: Deficit = Dense (Everything in labs is high/concentrated). Excess = Enhanced volume (Weight is high).
